document.docAuthor: Berniker, Lily, Szerlip, Sigurd, Forero, Dimitri & Weirauch, Christiane

heading.emphasis:
Key to the species of the
crassipes
species group

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution is included in the key only when it aids in species identification, and is not included for all species.

paragraph.keyLead: - Body size larger, males usually more than 13 mm , females more than 14 mm ( Tab. 2 ); if male 13 mm or female 14 mm , never found in the Western United States , Northern Mexico or the Baja peninsula....................................... 3

2 Pronotum dark red, fore tibia uniformly dark red, corium dark red ( Fig. 1G ). Restricted to Baja California Sur , Mexico ...............................................................
Apiomerus peninsularis Berniker & Szerlip
, sp. nov.

- Pronotum black or orange-red, fore tibia banded with black and orange, corium orange to dark red ( Figs 1B , 16B ). Western U.S. , Baja peninsula and northwestern Mexico ........................
Apiomerus cazieri Berniker & Szerlip
, sp. nov.

3 Black, posterior pronotal margin and connexivum orange to dark red ( Fig. 1D ) ……….....
Apiomerus crassipes (Fabricius)
- Variously colored, but not matching above pattern........................................................... 4

keyLead.materialsCitation:
4 Males with dorsolateral lobes of the endosoma not divided into anterior and posterior portions, rather present as a single, folded sclerite with a lateral prolongation ( Fig. 8A ). Males and females with pronotum mostly black, sometimes with red at anterior or lateral edges, corium red, abdominal connexiva forming a continuous pale yellow to white margin around abdomen ( Figs 1A , 16A ). California (USA) and Baja California ( Mexico ).....
Apiomerus californicus Berniker & Szerlip
, sp. nov

paragraph.keyLead: - Males with dorsolateral lobes of the endosoma clearly divided into proximal and distal portions ( Figs 8B, 8C ). Male and female color not as above, if similar in color, never found in California ( USA ) or Baja California ( Mexico ).............. 5

6 Pronotum mostly black, sometimes with red at anterior or lateral edges, corium and legs dark red ( Fig. 1H )..........................................................................................
Apiomerus rufipennis (Fallou)

- Pronotal lobes orange or red, each with transverse black band along posterior margin, corium and leg color orange or red ( Fig. 1J ).....................................................
Apiomerus wygodzinskyi Berniker & Szerlip
, sp. nov.

7 Median process of pygophore a broad, deep U-shape ( Fig. 2C ), abdominal venter usually black.....................................................................
Apiomerus cooremani
Costa Lima, Campos Seabra and Hathaway

8 Fore femur and tibia uniformly black, each abdominal connexival segment with a pale yellow to white stripe at anterior edge of segment, resulting in a banded appearance in dorsal and lateral view ( Figs 1F , 17A )............................................................................................
Apiomerus montanus Berniker & Szerlip
, sp. nov.

- Fore femur and tibia red to brown, sometimes with apical half of tibia black, but never uniformly black, abdominal connexivum forming a continuous margin around abdomen ( Figs 1F, 1I , 16D , 17B )....................................... 9

keyLead.materialsCitation:
9 Males 12.5–14.2 mm , females 13.9–16.2 mm ( Tab. 2 ), fore and mid legs red with apical half of tibia black. Florida peninsula and Florida keys ( Fig. 1E , 16D )................................
Apiomerus floridensis Berniker & Szerlip
, sp. nov

paragraph.keyLead:
- Males 14.1–16.5 mm , females 14.2–17.3 mm ( Tab. 2 ), legs red to brown, not always in above pattern. North Dakota south into Mexico , Arizona east through Texas and along Gulf Coast, never in the Florida peninsula ( Fig. 1I , 17B )................................................................................................
Apiomerus spissipes (Say)
